description:
With less than an hour to go, [b]the #93 Peugeot and the #12 Jota had converged on track[/b] and were back on the lead lap, 40 seconds behind the leader. They fought for second place, but [b]a potential win was at stake[/b] too if the leader needed repairs. Going for an undercut, Jota brought their car first, but Peugeot managed to keep their car in front after their stop.

In parallel, the [b]#38 Jota had to retire after a problem with the hybrid system[/b] while fighting for 6th place. The leader #6 Porsche and both Alpines had a final scare each, as they separately went off at the infamous Turn 9 one last time.

Less than 10 laps remaining, [b]the leader #6 Porsche had enough margin on track to perform a quick stop[/b] to glue a number panel printed in paper to the remains of the left bodywork, saving themselves any trouble. Half a minute behind, [b]the #93 Peugeot, #12 Jota and #5 Porsche fought for podium positions[/b], but drama struck with only 2 laps to go, as [b]the #93 Peugeot lost power and came to a halt[/b]. Trying to salvage points, it continued running with electric energy, but [b]it earned a disqualification[/b] for deploying it at lower speeds than permitted.

[b]The #6 Porsche comfortably won the race[/b] and [b]the #12 Jota managed to fend the #5 Porsche off in-extremis for second place[/b]. Behind, [b]the #2 Cadillac recovered up to fourth after saving a stop[/b] and [b]the #83 AF Corse completed the top-5[/b] with a very solid debut. Disappointment for Toyota, the current champions, who did not have the pace; and for the Ferrari, who were struck with multiple issues. In contrast, [b]a satisfying race for the #35 Alpine, the only newcomer car in the points[/b].
